lead_paragraph: HADID--Zaha Mohammad, died on Thursday, 31 March 2016 in Miami, USA. She was 65. Zaha was born on 31 October 1950 in Baghdad, Iraq. She studied at the American University of Beirut and the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London. Founder of Zaha Hadid Architects, her pioneering vision redefined architecture for the 21st century and captured imaginations across the globe. Her built projects include the Vitra Fire Station in Weil Am Rhein, Germany; Rosenthal Center for Contemporary Art in Cincinnati; BMW Central Building in Leipzig, Germany; MAXXI: Italian National Museum of 21st Century Arts in Rome; London Aquatics Centre for the 2012 Olympic Games; Guangzhou Opera House in China; Heydar Aliyev Centre in Baku; Serpentine Sackler Gallery in London; Issam Fares Institute at the American University of Beirut and Oxford University's Middle East Centre at St. Antony's College. She was committed to education and taught at institutions around the world including Harvard University, Columbia University, Yale University and the University of Applied Arts in Vienna. Zaha was the first woman to be awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004, won the RIBA Stirling Prize in 2010 and 2011, was made a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2012 and was the first woman to be awarded the Royal Gold Medal in her own right in 2016. She also received the Commandeur de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres from the Republic of France and the Praemium Imperiale from the Japan Art Association. Her brilliance and creativity changed the field of architecture with new spatial concepts and bold visionary forms. She will be greatly missed. Zaha is survived by her brother Haytham Hadid, her nephew Hussein Haytham Hadid, her niece Rana Haytham Hadid and the family of her late brother Foulath Mohammad Hadid. Prayers for her soul will be held at London Central Mosque today, Wednesday, 6 April 2016 at 12:30pm. To pay respects to her family and sign books of condolence the Serpentine Sackler Gallery, London will be open between 2:00pm and 7:00pm on Thursday the 7th and Friday the 8th of April, 2016. 1/3
